ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Infinite parallel plates located at x3=0 and x3=d>0. The outward pointing normals to the plates are shown. Note that since the two normals point in opposite directions their components differ by a minus sign at each plate; ân3(0)=n3(d)=1=n3(0)=ân3(d). The physical constraint that at the plates there is no current normal to the surface is illustrated.

A diagrammatic layout of the irreducible representations (irreps) of Sp(2,C) for massless fields with discrete spin. Each irrep is labelled by a pair of numbers (i,j) where i,j=0,12,1,32,â¦. The spin values corresponding to the (i,j)th-representation are Â±|s| where |s|=i+j. An (i,j)-irrep for which i=0 or j=0 is called an âouterâ irrep, otherwise it is an âinnerâ irrep. Fields belonging to the outer irrep (i,0) directly describe a spin i particle, whereas those belonging to the outer irrep (0,i) directly describe a spin âi particle. The number directly below each (i,j)-irrep equals the complex-dimension d=(2i+1)(2j+1) of the irrep immediately above it. Directly above the relevant (i,j)-irreps is a list of fields. Under a Lorentz transformation, each of these fields transforms in some way according to the irrep below it (c.f. AppendixÂ A.2). For example, in the two-spinor calculus formalism a field belonging to the (i,j)th-irrep is denoted Ï(a1...a2i)(aÌ1...aÌ2j) where (a1...an) denotes total symmetrisation of the indices a1,â¦,an (c.f. AppendixÂ A.2). Since lower spins have been studied more extensively than higher spins, lower spin values possess more corresponding fields. This is particularly evident in the electromagnetic case |s|=1 (c.f. SectionÂ 2.1.2). For s=0 the only corresponding field is the scalar field Ï. For |s|=12 we have in addition to Ïa and ÏaÌ, the DiracâWeyl two-column spinors ÏR and ÏL, which make up the usual Dirac bispinor. The irreps of the form (i,i) correspond to totally symmetric traceless rank 2i2i-tensors over Minkowski spacetime (c.f. AppendixÂ A.3). Such tensors represent field potentials. The first of the (i,i) irreps is the (12,12) vector irrep occurring for |s|=1. It has corresponding field potential AÎ¼, which denotes the electromagnetic four-potential. The next is the (1,1) irrep occurring for |s|=2, and corresponding to which hÎ¼Î½ is the field potential describing linearised gravity (c.f. SectionÂ 3.2.2).

A schematic representation of the field solutions corresponding to the first few allowed values of k3 from Eq. (32). Fermionic field solutions corresponding to the three values k3=nÏ/2d,n=1,3,5 are represented by solid orange curves, while bosonic field solutions corresponding to the three values k3=nÏ/d,n=1,2,3 are represented by dashed blue curves. The aperiodic orange curves clearly illustrate that periodic BCs cannot be used in conjunction with fermionic fields. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

head.ce:title: The Casimir effect for fields with arbitrary spin

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: The School of Physics and Astronomy, University of Leeds, Leeds, LS2 9JT, United Kingdom

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: The School of Physics and Astronomy, University of Leeds

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The Casimir force arises when a quantum field is confined between objects that apply boundary conditions to it. In a recent paper we used the two-spinor calculus to derive boundary conditions applicable to fields with arbitrary spin in the presence of perfectly reflecting surfaces. Here we use these general boundary conditions to investigate the Casimir force between two parallel perfectly reflecting plates for fields up to spin-2. We use the two-spinor calculus formalism to present a unified calculation of well-known results for spin-1/2 (Dirac) and spin-1 (Maxwell) fields. We then use our unified framework to derive new results for the spin-3/2 and spin-2 fields, which turn out to be the same as those for spin-1/2 and spin-1. This is part of a broader conclusion that there are only two different Casimir forces for perfectly reflecting platesâone associated with fermions and the other with bosons.

ce:section.ce:para: In 1948 Casimir and Polder published a long, technically complex paper about the influence of retardation on the van der Waals forceÂ [1]. The stated goal of their work was to account for discrepancies between experiments and theory concerning colloidal suspensions of large particlesÂ [2]. However, the work took on a whole new significance when, after discussing the results with Bohr, Casimir was inspired to try and re-explain his and Polderâs results using the relatively new idea that the quantised electromagnetic field undergoes vacuum fluctuations. A short time later, Casimir published his now-famous paperÂ [3] on the force of attraction between two infinite perfectly conducting parallel plates, whose presence modifies the quantised electromagnetic vacuum field. This force came to be known as the Casimir force. The calculation inÂ [3] reproduces the results of the much more involved calculation inÂ [1], but is remarkable in its simplicity and elegance, while also providing one of the very few macroscopic manifestations of quantum field theory. The Casimir force is extremely weak so was initially nothing more than a theoretical curiosity, but as experimental methods improved the effect became measurable, and this led to rapidly increasing attention from the 1970s onwards. Since then there has been a profusion of extensions of Casimirâs original work, which look into imperfectly conducting plates and different physical geometriesÂ [4â8]. There have also been a number of experimental confirmations of the effectÂ [9â11]. The existence of the Casimir effect is often cited in standard quantum field theory textbooks as the primary justification for the reality of vacuum fluctuations, though such interpretations carry some controversyÂ [12].

A fluctuating vacuum is a general feature of quantum fields, of which the free Maxwell field considered inÂ [1â12] is but one example. Fermionic fields such as that describing the electron, also undergo vacuum fluctuations, consequently one expects to find Casimir effects associated with such fields whenever they are confined in some way. Such effects were first investigated in the context of nuclear physics, within the so-called âMIT bag modelâ of the nucleonÂ [13]. In the bag-model one envisages the nucleon as a collection of fermionic fields describing confined quarks. These quarks are subject to a boundary condition at the surface of the âbagâ that represents the nucleonâs surface. Just as in the electromagnetic case, the bag boundary condition modifies the vacuum fluctuations of the field, which results in the appearance of a Casimir forceÂ [14â18]. This force, although very weak at a macroscopic scale, can be significant on the small length scales encountered in nuclear physics. It therefore has important consequences for the physics of the bag-model nucleonÂ [19].

The Maxwell and Dirac fields are both spinor fields, though the former is not usually described as such. It is possible to write Maxwellâs equations in a form identical to the DiracâWeyl equation that describes massless spin-12 fermionsÂ [20]. This naturally leads one to the question as to whether it is possible to use a spinor formalism to describe the Casimir effect for the Dirac (spin-12) and Maxwell (spin-1) fields in a unified way. We have shownÂ [21] that such a unification can be accomplished using the two-spinor calculus formalism introduced by van der WaerdenÂ [22]. Moreover, this unification naturally lends itself to a generalisation, which is applicable to confined higher-spin fields. These fields include the spin-2 field associated with the so-called graviton, which appears in linearised quantum gravity, and its supersymmetric partner the spin-32 gravitino.

In this paper we will present specific results for the Casimir force associated with the fields up to spin-2. We organise our work by noting that calculations of Casimir forces broadly follow the following three steps:

ce:list-item.ce:para: The statement of one or more boundary conditions governing how the considered field behaves at material surfaces. These can be mathematically convenient (examples include DirichletÂ [23], NeumannÂ [24], RobinÂ [25] and periodicÂ [26,27] BCs) or physically-motivated (those imposed by electromagnetismÂ [4] or by the bag modelÂ [13] for example).

The determination of a set of field solutions that obey the boundary conditions specified in step 1. In the simplest cases this can be achieved by direct solution of the equations of motion. However, this step is usually non-trivial, and has resulted in the development of numerous techniques including the so-called macroscopic QEDÂ [28], worldline numericsÂ [29], the âproximity-force approximationâÂ [30,31], certain scattering theory based methodsÂ [32], and many more.

The substitution of the field solutions found in step 2 into an expression for the vacuum energy of the relevant field. Upon suitable regularisation and the dropping of any boundary-independent terms, one is left with the Casimir force for some combination of: a field (Maxwell, Dirac, etc.), a boundary condition, and a physical geometry.

ce:section.ce:para: We will begin in SectionÂ 2 by reviewing the generalised, physically-motivated boundary conditions presented inÂ [21]. We then find explicit field solutions for the parallel-plate geometry, and hence accomplish steps 1 and 2 given above. In SectionÂ 3 we will carry out the final step above by computing specific values for the Casimir force associated with the massless fields up to spin-2.

In this section we review our generalisation of the boundary conditions (BCs) employed in the calculation of the Casimir effect associated with the spin-12 and spin-1 fields. To do this we use the two-spinor calculus formalism presented in AppendixÂ A. Further details of the two-spinor calculus formalism can be found, for example, inÂ [33â35] and the references therein.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Unified physical boundary conditions for massless spin-12 and spin-1 fields

ce:section.ce:para: We begin by considering the simplest spin fieldâthe spin-12 massless DiracâWeyl field. We adopt the two-spinor calculus formalism laid out in AppendixÂ A. The spin-12 massless field is described by a pair of square-root KleinâGordon equations, which in the massless case are decoupled; (1)ÏÎ¼aÌaâÎ¼Ïa=0,ÏÌÎ¼aaÌâÎ¼ÏaÌ=0 where Ïa and ÏaÌ are spin-12 massless quantum fields describing right and left-helicities respectively. The usual Dirac bispinor can be constructed through a direct sum of fields proportional to Ï and Ï.

We wish to calculate the Casimir effect associated with the massless spin-12 field due to the presence of two perfectly reflecting parallel plates orthogonal to the x3-axis. We assume that one plate is located at x3=0 and that the other is located at x3=d>0 as shown in Fig.Â 1. The physical constraint we impose on the fields is that there be no particle-current normal to the surfaces at x3=0,d Â [17]; (2)nÎ¼(0,d)jÎ¼(0,d)=0 where nÎ¼(0,d)=(0,0,0,â1) are components of the outward-pointing unit normals to the surfaces at 0 and d respectively, and jÎ¼ are the components of the spin-12 particle-current vector. In terms of the two-spinors in Eq. (1), Eq. (2) reads [c.f. Eq. (A.13)] (3)naÌa(0,d)jaaÌ(0,d)=naÌa(0,d)Ïa(0,d)ÏaÌ(0,d)=0. This condition will hold if we impose the BCsÂ [17](4)nÎ¼(0,d)ÏÎ¼aÌa(0,d)Ïa(0,d)â¡Â±Ï3aÌaÏa(0,d)=ÏaÌ(0,d), where the (normalised) Pauli matrices {ÏÎ¼} are defined in Eq. (A.10). The + sign in Eq. (4) corresponds to the case x3=0, and the â sign to the case x3=d. To prove that Eq. (4) implies Eq. (3), one first multiplies Eq. (4) through by ÏaÌ(0,d). The left-hand-side then equals nÎ¼(0,d)jÎ¼(0,d) while the right-hand-side equals ÏaÌ(0,d)ÏaÌ(0,d)=ÏÌ(Ï(0,d),Ï(0,d))â¡0, where ÏÌ is the symplectic form on the spinor-space SÌ [c.f. AppendixÂ A]. This completes the proof. We note that the BCs in Eq. (4) are nothing but the usually employed BCs in the calculation of the spin-12 Casimir effectÂ [13,17].

We now Fourier-expand the fields Ïa and ÏaÌ in plane-wave superpositions as follows: Ïa(x)=â«d3kua(k)(bR(k)eâikÎ¼xÎ¼+dLâ (k)eikÎ¼xÎ¼)(5)ÏaÌ(x)=â«d3kuaÌ(k)(dR(k)eâikÎ¼xÎ¼+bLâ (k)eikÎ¼xÎ¼). Here k0â¡Ïâ|k|, and the label R (for right) corresponds to the helicity Î»=12 while the label L corresponds to the helicity Î»=â12. The function ua(k) and its charge-conjugate uaÌ(k) are (suitably normalised) momentum-space single-particle right and left-helicity wavefunctions respectively. The bÎ»(k) and bÎ»â (k) are annihilation and creation operators for particles with momentum k and helicity Î», and the dÎ»(k) and dÎ»â (k) are the corresponding anti-particle operators. Altogether these operators satisfy the fermionic anti-commutation relations (6){bÎ»(k),bÎ»â²â (kâ²)}={dÎ»(k),dÎ»â²â (kâ²)}=Î´Î»Î»â²Î´(kâkâ²). The expansions in Eq. (5) and anti-commutation relations in Eq. (6) allow us to express the total energy of the spin-12 massless field (including both helicities) as (7)H12=â«d3kâÎ»=Â±12Ï(bÎ»â (k)bÎ»(k)+dÎ»â (k)dÎ»(k)â1).

In order to deduce the values of momentum k allowed by the BCs in Eq. (4) it suffices to consider the following positive-energy single-particle plane-wave solution of the DiracâWeyl equation (1) for Ïa; (8)Ïa(x)=eâiÏtÏa(x),Ïa(x)=ua(k)eikâ x. If this solution is to be non-trivial, i.e.,Â such that ua(k) is not identically zero, then it cannot satisfy the BCs in Eq. (4). In other words the possibility of a completely free solution is negated by the presence of the plates, which evidently must modify the free solution in some way. We make the ansatzÂ [13,17](9)Ïa(x)=(Ï0aaÌeikâ¥â xâ¥+Ï3aaÌeâik3x3)uaÌ(k) where vâ¥â(v1,v2,0) denotes the projection of the three-vector v onto the x1âx2 plane. Making this ansatz constitutes the physically reasonable assumption that the effect of the plates is to flip the sign of x3 in Eq. (8). The modified solution (9) satisfies the BC in Eq. (4) at x3=0 identically. It will also satisfy the BC corresponding to x3=d provided that (10)cos(k3d)=0. Thus, given the solution in Eq. (9) the BCs in Eq. (4) restrict the values of k3 and hence k to (11)k3=nÏ2d,k=(k1,k2,nÏ2d),n=1,3,5,â¦. When used in conjunction with Eqs. (7) and (11), the above restricted values of k yield the usual Casimir force associated with the spin-12 field between two perfectly reflecting parallel plates (c.f. SectionÂ 3.1.1). In SectionÂ 2.2 it will be shown that with a straightforward generalisation of the BCs in Eq. (4), the above values of k turn out to be the same for any fermionic field.

The massless spin-1 field is the familiar field of Maxwell electrodynamics. In the two-spinor calculus formalism the Maxwell field is described by a pair of symmetric spin-tensors Ïab and ÏaÌbÌ corresponding to the right and left-helicity states of the photon respectively. The equations of motion analogous to those in (1) are the square-root KleinâGordon equations (12)ÏÎ¼aÌaâÎ¼Ïab=0,ÏÌÎ¼aaÌâÎ¼ÏaÌbÌ=0.

The relation of the spin-tensors above to the more conventional electromagnetic three-vectors is most easily achieved through the complex RiemannâSilberstein vector FâE+iB, where E and B are the electric and magnetic fields respectively. The vectors F and Fâ can be viewed as complex three-vectors corresponding to the right and left-helicity states of the photonÂ [36]. If one replaces the imaginary unit i in these definitions with the volume form I on Minkowski spacetime E1,3 and views the fields E and B as bivectors E and B over E1,3, then one obtains the familiar electromagnetic field tensor Fâ¡E+IB and its reverse Fâ â¡EâIB. Here the juxtaposition IB denotes the Clifford (geometric) product of I and B Â [37]. One can also describe the electromagnetic field in terms of the dual tensor GââFâ¡âIF where â denotes the Hodge-dual. Clearly each of the objects Ïab, F and F (or G) constitutes a different organisation of the six real degrees of freedom (including gauge degrees of freedom) that describe the physical electromagnetic field.

Relating the Maxwell spin-tensor Ïab to the RiemannâSilberstein vector F we haveÂ [36](13)Ïab=(âF1+iF2F3F3F1+iF2), and relating Ïab to the electromagnetic bivector FÎ¼Î½ we have [c.f. Eq. (A.13)]Â [33](14)FÎ¼Î½=ÏÎ¼aÌaÏÎ½bÌbFaaÌbbÌ,FaaÌbbÌ=ÏaÌbÌÏab+ÏabÏaÌbÌ. Although either of the above relations suffices in order to relate the two-spinor treatment of electrodynamics to the more widely-known approaches, we choose to make use of the former relation (13). Using Eq. (13) it is straightforward to show that the equations in (12) are equivalent to the free Maxwell equation (15)iâtF=âÃF and its complex-conjugate.

In determining the appropriate BCs to impose for the calculation of the Casimir effect in the spin-1 case, one must contend with the fact that there exists no local particle-current vector for massless fields with spin greater than 12 Â [38]. Thus, for the Maxwell field in particular, an alternative physical current jÎ¼ must be chosen in order to obtain a condition analogous to Eq. (2). As is well-known, one of the few local observables associated with photons is their energyâdensityÂ [39,36]. A natural choice for jÎ¼ in the spin-1 case is therefore the energyâcurrent (16)jÎ¼âTÎ¼0=12(Fâ Fâ,iFÃFâ)=(12(E2+B2),EÃB) where TÎ¼Î½ are the components of the symmetric energyâmomentum tensor of the Maxwell field. The physical constraint expressed by Eq. (2) with jÎ¼ given by Eq. (16) is ensured if one assumes that (17)n(0,d)â B(0,d)=0,n(0,d)ÃE(0,d)=0 where as before n(0) and n(d) are normal to the surfaces at x3=0 and d respectively. The analogy between the spin-12 and spin-1 cases becomes obvious when Eqs. (16) and (17) are written in terms of the Maxwell spin-tensor Ïab. To this end we note that using Eq. (13) the energyâmomentum tensor TÎ¼Î½ can be written [c.f. Eq. (A.13)] (18)TÎ¼Î½=ÏÎ¼aÌaÏÎ½bÌbTaaÌbbÌ,TaaÌbbÌ=ÏabÏaÌbÌ. Within the two-spinor calculus formalism there is a clear analogy between the spin-1 energyâmomentum spin-tensor TaaÌbbÌ=ÏabÏaÌbÌ, and the spin-12 particle-current jaaÌ=ÏaÏaÌ. As such, substituting the expression for TÎ¼0 given by Eq. (18) with Î½â¡0, into Eq. (2) yields (19)nÎ¼(0,d)jÎ¼(0,d)=naÌa(0,d)Ï0bÌbTaaÌbbÌ(0,d)â¡naÌa(0,d)Ï0bÌbÏab(0,d)ÏaÌbÌ(0,d)=0, which is the spin-1 version of Eq. (3). This condition will necessarily hold if we impose the BCs (20)nÎ¼(0,d)nÎ½(0,d)ÏÎ¼aÌaÏÎ½bÌbÏab(0,d)â¡Ï3aÌaÏ3bÌbÏab(0,d)=ÏaÌbÌ(0,d) which is clearly the spin-1 version of Eq. (4). To see that Eqs. (17) and (20) are equivalent one need only expand the sums in Eq. (20), which gives (21)Ï00(0,d)=Ï0Ì0Ì(0,d),Ï01(0,d)=âÏ0Ì1Ì(0,d). Using Eq. (13) it is easy to show that these conditions are equivalent to Eq. (17). The BCs in Eq. (20) written in terms of Ïab, are therefore completely equivalent to the usual BCs [in Eq. (17)] employed in the calculation of the electromagnetic Casimir effectÂ [3].

There still remains the proof that the BCs in Eq. (20) imply nÎ¼(0,d)TÎ¼0(0,d)=0. This proof is not as straightforward as the proof given in the spin-12 case. There we were able to make use of the anti-symmetry of the symplectic form on the spinor space SÌ, but such a strategy will obviously fail if the field under consideration is bosonic, i.e.,Â is described by an evenly ranked spin-tensor. However, a more brute force proof involving the use of Eq. (21) is available in the spin-1 case. In SectionÂ 2.2 we specify generalised BCs associated with an arbitrary spin-m2 field [Eq. (29)], and prove in AppendixÂ B that they imply the vanishing of the normal component of the relevant local current [Eq. (28)]. In this context the Maxwell field simply corresponds to the special case m=2.

Before moving on to determine the allowed values of k for the spin-1 field, we note that a significant difference between Eqs. (20) and (4), is that Eq. (20) involves an even number of factors of nÎ¼ rather than an odd number. Thus, the boundary condition is the same for both the x3=0 and x3=d cases, rather than differing by a minus sign as is the case in Eq. (4) for the spin-12 field. We will see quite generally in SectionÂ 2.2, that this is the crucial difference between the BCs for fermionic (half odd-integer spin) and bosonic (integer-spin) fields.

Now, using Eq. (20) the determination of the allowed values of k3 in the spin-1 case exactly mirrors the procedure used above for the spin-12 field. We employ the usual expression for the quantised energy of the Maxwell field (22)H1âT00=â«d3kâÎ»=Â±1Ï(aÎ»â (k)aÎ»(k)+12) where aÎ»(k) and aÎ»â (k) are bosonic annihilation and creation operators satisfying the commutation relation (23)[aÎ»(k),aÎ»â²â (kâ²)]=Î´Î»Î»â²Î´(kâkâ²). In order to determine the values of k allowed by the BCs in Eq. (20), we consider in exact analogy to the spin-12 case, the following modified positive-energy solutions of the Maxwell equations (12)Ïab(x)=eâiÏtÏab(x),(24)Ïab(x)=(Ï0aaÌÏ0bbÌeikâ¥â xâ¥+Ï3aaÌÏ3bbÌeâik3x3)uaÌbÌ(k) where uab(k) is a momentum-space right-helicity single-particle spin-tensor, analogous to ua(k) for the spin-12 field. As in the spin-12 case the modified solution satisfies the BC in Eq. (20) at x3=0 identically. It will also satisfy the BC at x3=d provided (25)sin(k3d)=0, which is the case if and only if (26)k3=nÏd,k=(k1,k2,nÏd),n=0,1,2,â¦. These values of k are usually found by more conventional means involving the electric and magnetic fields and the BCs in Eq. (17). Along with Eq. (22) they can be used to obtain the well-known electromagnetic Casimir force first found inÂ [3] (c.f. SectionÂ 3.1.2). In the following SectionÂ 2.2 we generalise the BCs in Eq. (20) to show that the above values of k turn out to be the allowed values for any bosonic field.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Generalised physical boundary conditions for massless fields with higher spin
ce:section.ce:para: Given the analogy between the spin-12 and spin-1 fields described above, the extension of the physical BCs in Eqs. (4) and (20) to higher-spin fields now naturally presents itself. Initially for higher spin fields the identification of a local physical current to use in conjunction with Eq. (2) may seem problematic, but we have effectively already tackled this problem in adapting the spin-12 BCs to the spin-1 case. The BCs for any massless higher spins should evidently involve the physical fields directly involved in the description of the right and left-helicity states. These fields belong to the (carrier spaces of the) âouterâ (rather than the âinnerâ) irreducible representations of the symplectic group Sp(2,C). This terminology is clarified by Fig.Â 2. The physical fields belonging to the outer representations are those that appear explicitly in the square-root (massless) KleinâGordon equations, which describe the physical dynamics of the free system. For a spin-m2 field these equations read (27)ÏÎ¼aÌ1a1âÎ¼Ïa1a2a3...am=0,ÏÌÎ¼a1aÌ1âÎ¼ÏaÌ1aÌ2aÌ3...aÌm=0. Specifying the appropriate BCs in terms of the outer field Ïa1...am clearly avoids any discussion regarding the use of unphysical inner field potentials, which are often used in the description of higher spins.

Generalising the local currents encountered in the spin-12 and spin-1 cases, we begin by defining for a spin-m2 field the local current (28)jÎ¼(m)âÏÎ¼aÌ1a1Ï0aÌ2a2â¦Ï0aÌmamÏa1â¦amÏaÌ1â¦aÌm, which due to the first equation of motion in (27), satisfies the local continuity equation âÎ¼jÎ¼(m)=0. Generalising now the spin-12 and spin-1 BCs in Eqs. (4) and (20), we impose for a spin-m2 field the BCs (29)nÎ¼1(0,d)â¦nÎ¼m(0,d)ÏÎ¼1aÌ1a1â¦ÏÎ¼maÌmamÏa1â¦am(0,d)=ÏaÌ1â¦aÌm(0,d), which are the same generalised BCs first given inÂ [21]. We prove in AppendixÂ B that these BCs imply that jÎ¼(m) satisfies the physical constraint given in Eq. (2), i.e.,Â nÎ¼(0,d)jÎ¼(0,d;m)=0. For fermionic fields m is odd, which implies that the BCs in Eq. (29) contain an odd number of factors of nÎ¼(0,d)=(0,0,0,Â±1). This means that when x3=d the BC differs by a minus sign compared with when x3=0. In contrast, for bosonic fields m is even, so the BC is the same for both the x3=d and x3=0 cases.

To determine the allowed values of k3 due to the BCs in Eq. (29), we use in analogy to the spin-12 and spin-1 cases, the following modified single-particle positive-energy solution to the first of the equations in (27)Ïa1â¦am(x)=eâiÏtÏa1â¦am(x),(30)Ïa1â¦am(x)â(Ï0a1aÌ1â¦Ï0amaÌmeikâ¥â xâ¥+Ï3a1aÌ1â¦Ï3amaÌmeâik3x3)uaÌ1â¦aÌm(k) where ua1â¦am(k) is a momentum-space single-particle positive-energy spin-tensor. In complete analogy to the spin-12 and spin-1 cases, substituting the solution above into Eq. (29) implies cos(k3d)=0,modd(31)sin(k3d)=0,meven. This gives the allowed values of k3 and k as k3=nÏ2d,k=(k1,k2,nÏ2d),n=1,3,5,â¦modd(32)k3=nÏd,k=(k1,k2,nÏd),n=0,1,2,â¦meven. In Fig.Â 3 we give a schematic representation of field solutions corresponding to the first few allowed values of k3 specified above.

According to the generalised BCs in Eq. (29) the two sets of energyâmomentum values in (32) are the only two possible, and they correspond to fermionic and bosonic fields respectively. A significant implication of these general results is that periodic BCs cannot be applied to a physically confined fermionic field between two parallel plates, because for fermionic fields the BCs are necessarily different at the two surfaces as is lucidly illustrated in Fig.Â 3. This means for example, that the approach adopted inÂ [26] where periodic BCs were imposed on the spin-32 field, is unphysical.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The Casimir effect for arbitrary spin fields
ce:section.ce:para: Having obtained according to the BCs in Eq. (29), the allowed values of energyâmomentum for a field with arbitrary spin, we now look to calculate the resulting Casimir force.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The Casimir effect for spin-12 and spin-1 fields
ce:section.ce:para: Calculating the Casimir forces associated with the spin-12 and spin-1 fields is a textbook exercise, so we review it here only very briefly, with an eye towards extending the calculation to the case of higher spin fields.

The energy associated with the massless spin-12 field is given in Eq. (7). Our strategy in calculating the Casimir force is to initially restrict the field to a fictitious cavity upon which we impose periodic BCs. We will take the continuum limit in the k1 and k2-directions after having employed the allowed values of k given in Eq. (11). The vacuum energy inside the quantisation cavity is given by (33)E12vac=ââkâÎ»=Â±12Ï where Ï=|k|. Substituting into Eq. (33) the allowed values of k given in Eq. (11) and taking the continuum limit with respect to the k1 and k2-directions one obtainsÂ [17](34)E12vac(d)=â2ânoddâ«d2kâ¥(2Ï)2(k1)2+(k2)2+(nÏ2d)2=â1Ïânoddâ«nÏ/2dâdxx2. The integral above is divergent and requires regularisation. We adopt a conventional regularisation, which yields the finite vacuum energy (35)E12vac(d)=â1ÏlimÎ±â0â2âÎ±2ânoddâ«nÏ/2dâdxeâÎ±x=â1ÏlimÎ±â0â2âÎ±2(ÏdÎ±2âÏ24d+7Ï3Î±25760d3+O(Î±3))ââ7Ï22880d3. In the last line above a term linear in d, which gives a constant contribution to âE12vac(d)/âd has been ignored. The final result for the Casimir force associated with the massless spin-12 field between two perfectly reflecting parallel plates is therefore (36)F12(d)=ââE12vac(d)âd=â7Ï2960d4, which is well-knownÂ [13].

For the massless spin-1 field in a box with periodic BCs, the vacuum energy according to Eq. (22) is (37)E1vac=12âkâÎ»=Â±1Ï. It must be understood in the above expression that when any of the components ki vanish, there is only one independent polarisation Î». Substituting into Eq. (37) the allowed values of k given in Eq. (26), and as in the spin-12 case taking the continuum limit with respect to the k1 and k2-directions, one obtains [17](38)E1vac(d)=ân=0ââ²â«d2kâ¥(2Ï)2(k1)2+(k2)2+(nÏd)2=12ÏânâNâ²â«nÏ/dâdxx2 where followingÂ [17] we use a prime on the summation to indicate that for the value n=0 a factor of 12 must be inserted. The vacuum energy is as expected divergent, and we adopt the same regularisation as in the spin-12 case. This yields the finite vacuum energy (39)E1vac(d)=12ÏlimÎ±â0â2âÎ±2ânâNâ²â«nÏ/dâdxeâÎ±xââÏ2720d3 where as in the spin-12 case a term linear in d has been ignored. Thus, the final result for the Casimir force associated with the massless spin-1 field between two perfectly reflecting parallel plates is (40)F1(d)=ââE1vac(d)âd=âÏ2240d4, which is well-knownÂ [3].

The calculations above pertaining to the spin-12 and spin-1 fields reveal that the only ingredients necessary in order to obtain a value for the Casimir force, are an expression for the vacuum energy of the field under consideration, and a set of energyâmomentum values allowed by the BCs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The Casimir effect for spin-32 and spin-2 fields
ce:section.ce:para: To calculate the Casimir force associated with a higher spin field, one must first obtain an expression for the associated vacuum energy. This is much more problematic for higher spin fields than it is for the fields with spin sâ¤1. Higher spin fields possess additional gauge freedom, and the local energyâmomentum tensors associated with such fields are generally gauge-dependent. Fortunately the total energy may still be gauge-invariant, and this is the working assumption we will make here.

The most common description of massless spin-32 particles is through the RaritaâSchwinger fieldÂ [40], which consists of four four-component Dirac bispinors ÏÎ¼ where the index Î¼ labels the four distinct bispinors. The RaritaâSchwinger field belongs to the reducible representation Râ(12,12)â[(12,0)â(0,12)], which is build from the two outer spin-12 irreducible representations and the single inner spin-1 irreducible representation of Sp(2,C) Â [41] (c.f. Fig.Â 2). The representation R has (complex) dimension sixteen, whereas the two outer irreducible representations (32,0) and (0,32), that directly correspond to the right and left-helicity states of the physical spin-32 field, have dimension four (c.f. Fig.Â 2). This gives a total of eight degrees of freedom, but not all of these are dynamically independent. Gauge-fixing reduces the total number of physical degrees of freedom to four, which is precisely the number required to describe the right and left-helicity states of a massless spin-32 particle and its anti-particle. The RaritaâSchwinger field contains some twelve redundant degrees of freedom, and accordingly the associated equations of motion are invariant under the gauge transformation (41)ÏÎ¼â²=ÏÎ¼+âÎ¼Î¾. Although largely redundant the RaritaâSchwinger field is advantageous, because it can be manipulated in much the same way as the familiar Dirac field for spin-12 particles. It is for this reason that we use it to obtain an expression for the energy of the massless spin-32 field.

The RaritaâSchwinger Lagrangian can be written (42)â32=â12ÏµÎ¼Î½ÏÏÏÌÎ¼Î³5Î³ÏââÏÏÎ½ where fââÎ¼gâfâÎ¼gâ(âÎ¼f)g, the ÏµÎ¼Î½ÏÏ are totally anti-symmetric with Ïµ0123=1, the set {Î³Î¼,Î³5} consists of the usual Dirac matrices with Î³5âiÎ³0Î³1Î³2Î³3, and ÏÌÎ¼âÏÎ¼â Î³0 denotes the relativistic adjoint of ÏÎ¼. Under the gauge transformation in Eq. (41) the Lagrangian varies by a total divergence.

The twelve redundant degrees of freedom are eliminated using constraints. In particular, the generalised Coulomb gauge is obtained by imposing the constraintsÂ [42](43)Î³Î¼ÏÎ¼=04,âÎ¼ÏÎ¼=04,Ï0=04 where 04 denotes the four-column with all zero entries. Using the identity (44)ÏµÎ¼Î½ÏÏÎ³5Î³Ïâ¡i(gÎ¼Î½Î³ÏâgÎ¼ÏÎ³Î½âgÎ½ÏÎ³Î¼+Î³Î¼Î³ÏÎ³Î½) it is a straightforward exercise to verify that for the Lagrangian in Eq. (42) along with the constraints in (43), the EulerâLagrange equations yield the Dirac equation iÎ³Î¼âÎ¼ÏÎ½=04 and its adjoint i(âÎ¼ÏÌÎ½)Î³Î¼=04T. This in turn ensures that ÏÎ¼ (and its adjoint) satisfy the correct relativistic wave equation(45)â¡ÏÎ¼=04 where â¡ââÎ¼âÎ¼.

The constraints in (43) reduce the number of (complex) physical degrees of freedom to the four required in order to describe the right and left-helicity states of a massless spin-32 particle and its anti-particle. As an ansatz for ÏÎ¼ in Eq. (45), we therefore make the following Fourier expansionÂ [42](46)ÏÎ¼(x)=â«d3kâÎ»=Â±32[bÎ»(k)uÎ¼(k,Î»;x)+dÎ»â (k)vÎ¼(k,Î»;x)] where the bÎ»(k),bÎ»â (k) and dÎ»(k),dÎ»â (k) are annihilation and creation operators for particles and anti-particles respectively, which as in the spin-12 case satisfy the anti-commutation relations in Eq. (6). It is of course possible to invert Eq. (46) and its Hermitian-conjugate, and this means it is possible to define the bÎ»(k),bÎ»â (k) and dÎ»(k),dÎ»â (k) in terms of ÏÎ¼(x). The single-particle positive and negative-energy wavefunctions uÎ¼(k,Î»;x) and vÎ¼(k,Î»;x) are defined by uÎ¼(k,Î»;x)â12Ï(2Ï)3uÎ¼(k,Î»)eâikÎ½xÎ½,(47)vÎ¼(k,Î»;x)â12Ï(2Ï)3vÎ¼(k,Î»)eikÎ½xÎ½ where uÎ¼(k,Î») and vÎ¼(k,Î») satisfy the momentum-space counterparts of the constraints in (43). The positive and negative-energy wavefunctions are not linearly-independent and are related by vÎ¼(k,Î»;x)=iÎ³2Î³0uÎ¼â (k,Î»;x). The orthonormality requirements for uÎ¼(k,Î») and vÎ¼(k,Î») can be deduced from the required properties of uÎ¼(k,Î»;x) and vÎ¼(k,Î»;x) under a Lorentz boost, and readÂ [42]uÌÎ¼(k,Î»)Î³Î½uÎ¼(k,Î»â²)=vÌÎ¼(k,Î»)Î³Î½vÎ¼(k,Î»â²)=â2kÎ½Î´Î»Î»â²,(48)uÌÎ¼(k,Î»)Î³0vÎ¼(âk,Î»â²)=0.

Using the Lagrangian in Eq. (42) and the constraints in (43) we obtain the energyâdensity (49)â32=ââ32â(âtÏÎ½)âtÏÎ½ââ32=âi2ÏÌÎ½Î³iââiÏÎ½. Using this expression together with Eqs. (6), (46) and (48), the total energy can be written as in the spin-12 case as (50)H32=â«d3xâ32=â«d3kâÎ»=Â±32Ï(bÎ»â (k)bÎ»(k)+dÎ»â (k)dÎ»(k)â1).

Since the spin-32 field is fermionic, according to Eq. (32) the allowed values of k for the calculation of the Casimir force, are the same as in the spin-12 case. Moreover, because the vacuum energies in Eqs. (7) and (50) are identical, the calculation of the Casimir force from Eq. (50) is also the same as in the spin-12 case, with the final result given by Eq. (36).

The spin-2 field is most commonly described using a symmetric traceless tensor field hÎ¼Î½, which corresponds to the inner (1,1) irreducible representation of the symplectic group Sp(2,C) [c.f. AppendixÂ A.3 and Fig.Â 2]. This field can also be viewed as the first-order gravitational correction to the components of the Minkowski inner-product. If we expand the general âmetricâ tensor of curved spacetime as gÎ¼Î½(u)=gÎ¼Î½+uhÎ¼Î½+â¯, then Einsteinâs vacuum equations yield an equation for hÎ¼Î½ which coincides with the correct relativistic wave equation for a massless spin-2 particle (the so-called graviton). As expected, gauge-fixing constraints are required to reduce the number of degrees of freedom present in hÎ¼Î½ to those describing the physical right and left-helicities of the graviton.

These helicities are more directly described by symmetric spin-tensors Ïabcd and ÏaÌbÌcÌdÌ, which belong to the outer irreducible representations (2,0) and (0,2) respectively, and which satisfy the usual equations of motion (27). As in the spin-1 and spin-32 cases, it is these fields which belong to outer representations of Sp(2,C), that are in many ways more physically relevant than the gauge-dependent inner field potentials such as hÎ¼Î½ (c.f. Fig.Â 2).

A significant property of the field Ïabcd is that it can be used to define the so-called BelâRobinson tensor TÎ¼Î½ÏÏ, which is one of many possible gravitational versions of a local energyâmomentum tensorÂ [33]. As expected of an energyâmomentum tensor, TÎ¼Î½ÏÏ is totally symmetric, traceless and possesses certain positivity properties. It is also the natural analog of the energyâmomentum tensor TÎ¼Î½ found in electrodynamicsÂ [33]. This last property is most easily seen using the two-spinor calculus formalism, whereby (51)TÎ¼Î½ÏÏ=ÏÎ¼aÌaÏÎ½bÌbÏÏcÌcÏÏdÌdÏabcdÏaÌbÌcÌdÌ. Thus, the local current TÎ¼000 is the natural analog of the currents encountered in the spin-12 and spin-1 cases, and as such the generalised BCs in Eq. (29) imply that for the spin-2 field, it is the normal component of TÎ¼000 that vanishes at each plate.

In order to obtain an expression for the energy associated with the spin-2 field, we build on the early approach ofÂ [43] for the quantisation of linearised gravity. The starting point inÂ [43] is Schwingerâs action principleÂ [44], which is stated in terms of a Lagrangian of an extremely general form. This form includes the so-called Platini general-relativistic Lagrangian as a special case. The use of the PlatiniâLagrangian formulation of general relativity turns out to be a crucial feature of the approach adopted inÂ [43], because it circumvents a number of problems pertaining to the highly nonlinear nature of general relativity.

From here on we will employ the shorthand notation fij,kââkâfij and fij,klââlâkfij. This allows us to write the linearised (first-order) approximation to the PlatiniâLagrangian as (52)â2=hÎ½Ï[ÎÎ¼Î½Ï,Î¼â12(ÎÎ¼Î½Î¼,Ï+ÎÎ¼ÏÎ¼,Î½)]âgÎ½Ï[ÎÎ¼ÏÎ½â ÎÏÏÎ¼âÎÎ¼ÏÎ¼â ÎÏÎ½Ï] where 2fâ gâfg+gf, the hÎ¼Î½=hÎ½Î¼ are the first-order corrections to the components gÎ¼Î½ of the Minkowski inner-product, and the ÎÎ¼Î½Ï=ÎÎ¼ÏÎ½ are the components of the Levi-Civita connection over spacetime. To first-order in hÎ¼Î½ the connection coefficients can be written (53)ÎÎ¼Î½Ïâ12gÎ¼Ï(hÏÎ½,Ï+hÏÏ,Î½âhÎ½Ï,Ï). The (constrained) fields hij and Î0ij serve as canonical fields in the Hamiltonian formulation of linearised gravity given inÂ [43], which we review presently.

The variational principle used in conjunction with the Lagrangian in Eq. (52) yields the linearised equations of motionÂ [43]âthij=â2Î0ij+h0i,j+h0j,i,âthÎ¼0=âÎ´Î¼i(h00,iâÎi00)+2Î´Î¼0Î000,(54)âtÎ0ij=â12(hij,kk+hkk,ijâhki,jkâhkj,ikâk00,ij) where it is understood that all repeated indices i,j,k are to be summed over 1,2,3. The entire theory is invariant under the coordinate (gauge) transformationsÂ [43]hÎ¼Î½â²=hÎ¼Î½+Î¾Î½,Î¼+Î¾Î¼,Î½âgÎ¼Î½Î¾Ï,Ï,(55)Îâ²Î¼Î½Ï=ÎÎ¼Î½Ï+Î¾Î¼,Î½Ï and as such the variational principle also yields the following equations of constraintÂ [43]Îijk=12(hij,k+hik,j+hjk,i),ÎÎ¼i0=Î´Î¼k(âh0k,i+Î0ki)+12Î´Î¼0h00,i,(56)Î0ik,k=Î0kk,i,hij,ij=hii,jj. The constraints arise due to the presence of redundant gauge degrees of freedom, which must be eliminated via gauge fixing. A common choice of gauge in general relativity is the transverse traceless (TT) gauge, which is analogous to the Coulomb gauge in electrodynamics. In the TT-gauge the field hÎ¼Î½ satisfies (57)hÎ¼Î½,Î¼=0,hÎ¼Î¼=0,hÎ¼0=0, and the equations of motion (54) take on the following simple harmonic form, which is synonymous with the free dynamics generated by quadratic Hamiltonians; (58)âthij=â2Î0ijâtÎ0ij=â12hij,kk. Together the constraint hÎ¼0=0 and the equations of motion (58) ensure the correct relativistic wave equation (59)â¡hÎ¼Î½=0.

In order to proceed it will be helpful to count the number of physical degrees of freedom with which we are dealing. The TT-gauge constraints in (57) reduce the number of physical degrees of freedom in hÎ¼Î½ from ten to two. To see this note that there are nine separate equations in (57), but that only eight of these are independent, because the first constraint with Î½=0 is implied by the last. Thus, in total, we are left with four real degrees of freedom, two of which are contained in hij, and two of which are contained in âthij=â2Î0ij. This is precisely the number of physical degrees of freedom required to describe the two independent helicities of the graviton. As an ansatz for hÎ¼Î½ in Eq. (59), we therefore make the following Fourier expansion (60)hÎ¼Î½(x)=â«d3kâÎ»=Â±2[uÎ¼Î½(k,Î»;x)aÎ»(k)+uÌÎ¼Î½(k,Î»;x)aÎ»â (k)] where the single-particle wavefunctions uÎ¼Î½(k,Î»;x) are defined by (61)uÎ¼Î½(k,Î»;x)â12Ï(2Ï)3eÎ¼Î½(k,Î»)eâikÏxÏ in which eÎ¼Î½(k,Î») denotes a transverse traceless polarisation tensor. In Eq. (60) we have used aÎ»â (k) to denote the complex-conjugate of the complex number aÎ»(k) in anticipation of the quantum mechanical expression for hÎ¼Î½.

The polarisation tensors eÎ¼Î½(k,Î») in Eq. (61) possess the orthonormality and symmetry properties eÎ¼Î½(k,Î»)eÌÎ¼Î½(k,Î»â²)=2Î´Î»Î»â²,gÎ¼Î½eÎ¼Î½(k,Î»)=0,(62)eij(âk,Î»)=eij(k,Î»),ei0(âk,Î»)=âei0(k,Î»), which can be deduced from the required properties of uÎ¼Î½ under a Lorentz boost. If we now define the following inner-product over the Hilbert space of solutions to Eq. (59)(63)ãh,hâ²ãâi2â«d3xhÌÎ¼Î½(x)ââthÎ¼Î½â²(x)|t=0, we see that the normalisation of the polarisation tensors eÎ¼Î½(k,Î») has been chosen such that the wavefunctions uÎ¼Î½(k,Î»;x) satisfy the orthonormality conditions ãu(k,Î»),u(kâ²,Î»â²)ã=Î´Î»Î»â²Î´(kâkâ²),(64)ãuÌ(k,Î»),uÌ(kâ²,Î»â²)ã=âÎ´Î»Î»â²Î´(kâkâ²).

The mode expansion in Eq. (60) is consistent with the TT-gauge constraints in (57) provided we impose the following further restrictions on the polarisation tensors (65)kÎ¼eÎ¼Î½(k,Î»)=0,eÎ¼Î¼(k,Î»)=0,eÎ¼0(k,Î»)=0. The first two constraints above are consistent with the required behaviour of hÎ¼Î½ under a Lorentz boost. The third however, clearly shows that hÎ¼Î½ cannot transform in a Lorentz-covariant way. This situation is analogous to the one encountered in electrodynamics. Like the components AÎ¼ of the electromagnetic four-potential, the components hÎ¼Î½ are to be viewed as the components of a geometric field that is physically invariant under a larger transformation group including both Lorentz transformations and gauge transformations. The constraint hÎ¼0=0 is consistent with this broader notion of physical invariance.

Using now Eq. (58), we obtain from hÎ¼Î½ in Eq. (60) the following expression for Î0ij, which is the (negative of the) canonical momentum conjugate to hij(66)Î0ij(x)=i2â«d3kÏ2(2Ï)3âÎ»=Â±2(aÎ»(k)eij(k,Î»)eâikÏxÏâaÎ»â (k)eÌij(k,Î»)eikÏxÏ). It is of course possible to invert the expressions for hij [in Eq. (60)] and Î0ij given above. This means the aÎ»(k) and aÎ»â (k) can be defined in terms of the Fourier transforms of the canonical fields.

The energyâdensity can be calculated from the Lagrangian in Eq. (52) and after making use of the constraints (57) can be written (in the TT-gauge)Â [43](67)â2=ââ2â(âthÎ¼Î½)âthÎ¼Î½ââ2=(Î0ij)2+14(hij,k)2 where the indices i,j,k are each summed over 1,2,3. This yields the total energyÂ [43](68)H2=â«d3xâ2=â«d3x[(Î0ij)2+14(hij,k)2].

When the fields hij and Î0ij are interpreted as operators on some suitably defined Hilbert space, the above Hamiltonian together with the Heisenberg equation iâtO=[O,H2] yields the correct equations of motion (58), provided the canonical fields satisfy the following equal-time commutation relation, consistent with the TT-gauge constraintsÂ [43](69)[hij(x),Î0kl(xâ²)]=âiÎ´ijklTT(xâxâ²)âi2[(23Î´ijÎ´klâÎ´ikÎ´jlâÎ´ilÎ´jk)Î´(xâxâ²)]TT. The right-hand-side of the above equality attains meaning when the expression within the brackets is contracted with a suitably chosen three-dimensional symmetric test tensor fkl(xâ²) and is then integrated over a fixed time-slice. This procedure will yield some symmetric tensor gij(x), which in general, will not be transverse or traceless. The notation [â ]TT signifies that the transverse traceless component of gij(x) must then be taken, and it is this projection onto the TT subspace, which ensures Eq. (69) is consistent with the TT-gauge constraints in (57). In short, the distribution Î´ijklTT(xâxâ²) is defined by the integration condition (70)â«d3xâ²Î´ijklTT(xâxâ²)fij(xâ²)=fklTT(x) where fklTT(x) is the transverse traceless component of the symmetric tensor fkl(x). This situation is of course quite familiar from quantum electrodynamics in the Coulomb gauge whereby the right-hand-side of the canonical commutation relation that is analogous to Eq. (69), involves the transverse delta function Î´ijT(xâxâ²) Â [45]. In the spin-2 case however, one is dealing with three-dimensional symmetric tensors rather than three-dimensional vectors, and the appropriate distribution is therefore Î´ijklTT(xâxâ²). In terms of an integral in momentum-space Î´ijklTT(xâxâ²) admits the representation (71)Î´ijklTT(xâxâ²)=â«d3k2(2Ï)3âÎ»=Â±2eij(k,Î»)eÌkl(k,Î»)eikâ (xâxâ²), which is also reminiscent of the well-known Fourier transform representation of the transverse delta function Î´ijT(xâxâ²) Â [46].

To verify that the expression on the right-hand-side of Eq. (71) possesses the property specified in Eq. (70) we first note that any (suitably well-behaved) real transverse traceless symmetric tensor can be decomposed as (72)fijTT(x)=â«d3k(2Ï)3fÌijTT(k)eikâ x=â«d3k(2Ï)3âÎ»=Â±2eij(k,Î»)fÌÎ»(k)eikâ x where fÌijTT denotes the (three-dimensional) Fourier transform of fijTT, and fÌÎ»(k) denotes a complex Fourier coefficient labelled by helicity Î» and momentum k. We also make use of the following more complicated scalarâvectorâtensor decomposition of a (suitably well-behaved) real symmetric three-dimensional tensor (73)fij(x)=â«d3k(2Ï)3fÌij(k)eikâ x withÂ [47](74)fÌij=13fÌÎ´ij+(kËikËjâ13Î´ij)fÌs+kËifÌjv+kËjfÌiv+fÌijTT. Here kËâk/|k| and fÌ denotes the trace of fÌij. The scalar quantity fÌs and the vector quantity fÌv are defined in terms of the kËi, fÌij and fÌ, but their precise form need not be given in order to prove that Eq. (71) holds. Now, due to the constraints in (65), we have using Eqs. (72) and (74) that (75)âÎ»=Â±2eij(k,Î»)eÌkl(k,Î»)fÌÌij(k)=fÌÌklTT(k). Thus, substituting Eq. (71) and the complex-conjugate of Eq. (73) into the left-hand-side of Eq. (70), one readily obtains by making use of Eq. (75), the complex-conjugate of the right-hand-side of Eq. (72). This proves that Eq. (71) holds when used in conjunction with any (suitably well-behaved) real symmetric tensor.

Having established that Eq. (71) holds we can now check that our canonical formulation of linearised gravity is consistent with the mode expansions in Eqs. (60) and (66). Consistency is ensured if when the mode expansions are substituted into the commutation relation i[hij(x),Î0kl(xâ²)], one obtains the right-hand-side of Eq. (71). This will be the case provided the aÎ»(k) and aÎ»â (k) obey the bosonic commutation relation in Eq. (23). Thus, imposing the bosonic commutation relation between aÎ»(k) and aÎ»â (k), and substituting Eqs. (60) and (66) into Eq. (68), we obtain using Eq. (62) the expected expression for the energy of the massless spin-2 field; (76)H2=â«d3kâÎ»=Â±2Ï(aÎ»â (k)aÎ»(k)+12). This Hamiltonian together with the Heisenberg equation yields the correct equations of motion (54). Since the spin-2 field is bosonic, according to Eq. (32) the allowed values of k for the calculation of the Casimir force, are the same as in the spin-1 case. Moreover, because the vacuum energies in Eqs. (22) and (76) are identical, the calculation of the Casimir force from Eq. (76) is also the same as in the spin-1 case, with the final result given by Eq. (40).

Having obtained the Casimir forces associated with both the spin-32 and spin-2 fields, we are in a position to consider what might be called the super-gravitational Casimir force. In supergravity the graviton is paired with its supersymmetric partnerâthe spin-32 gravitino. The Lagrangian can be taken as a sum of uncoupled Lagrangians associated with the spin-32 and spin-2 fields respectively, plus a term involving additional auxiliary fields. In the case of pure gravitation these auxiliary fields vanish on the space of solutions to the equations of motionÂ [48]. We can therefore conjecture that the super-gravitational Casimir force is the sum of the fermionic and bosonic Casimir forces given in Eqs. (36) and (40) respectively.

In this paper we have used general physical BCs to calculate the Casimir force between two perfectly reflecting parallel plates for the massless quantum fields up to spin-2. For each spin value the generalised BCs imply that at the plates the normal component of a physically appropriate local-current vanishes. For the spin-12 (massless DiracâWeyl) field the appropriate current is the particle-current. For the spin-1 (Maxwell) field no particle-current exists, so the electromagnetic energyâcurrent occurs in its place. For the spin-2 (linearised gravitational) field neither a local particle-current nor a local energyâcurrent exists, so a current defined in terms of the BelâRobinson tensor occurs instead.

We have shown that the generalised BCs imply that the allowed values of energyâmomentum between two perfectly reflecting parallel plates are the same for all fermionic fields and the same for all bosonic fields. We have verified that these allowed values of energyâmomentum lead to two distinct Casimir forces, one associated with fermions and one associated with bosons. This has been achieved through the explicit calculation of the Casimir forces associated with the fields ranging from spin-12 up to spin-2. A significant implication of these general results is that periodic BCs cannot be applied to a fermionic field confined between two parallel plates. This renders certain previous investigations unphysical.

The results we have obtained open up numerous avenues for further investigation into Casimir forces, both for the more familiar spin-12 and spin-1 fields, and for higher-spin fields as well. An obvious extension of the present work lies in the diversification of the surface geometries and reflection properties assumed in the calculations. We have also already mentioned at the end of SectionÂ 3.2.2 a further possible extension of the present work into the arena of supersymmetric field theories. Yet another extension lies in the consideration of confined interacting massless fields, such as coupled spin-12 and spin-1 fields. In this case, in order to determine the allowed values of energyâmomentum, one would need to find modified single-particle solutions to the coupled equations of motion, which satisfy the physical constraints of giving no local spin-12 or spin-1 current normal to the surfaces.

ce:section.ce:label: A.1
ce:section.ce:para: The two-spinor calculus provides a means by which to build arbitrary irreducible representations of the (proper orthochronous) Lorentz group L+â. Representations up to a phase of L+â are in one-to-one correspondence with representations of its universal covering group SL(2,C), which is identical to the complex symplectic group Sp(2,C). Spinors are built using the two-dimensional complex symplectic vector spaces S and SÌ where a bar is used to denote the complex-conjugate space. The space S is the pair (V,Ï), where V is a two-dimensional complex vector space and Ï:VÃVâC is a complex symplectic (non-degenerate) form. Choosing a basis {fa}âV and employing the summation convention for repeated upper and lower indices we have (A.1)Ï=ÏafaâS,ÏÌ=ÏaÌfaÌâSÌ where we use bars rather than the more commonly used dots to distinguish between a spinor index and a conjugate-spinor index. Furthermore we rely entirely on the different indices in order to distinguish between the components of Ï and ÏÌ as well as between the basis vectors {fa} and their conjugates. With these index conventions matrix operations become particularly simple. If a matrix v has elements vab, then we have the following representations (A.2)vâvab,vÌâvaÌbÌ,vTâvba,vâ âvbÌaÌ where T and â denote matrix transposition and Hermitian conjugation respectively. A Hermitian matrix clearly has components vaaÌ (or vaÌa).

In order to construct arbitrary spinors one also uses the dual spaces Sâ,SÌâ. The dual Vâ of the (complex) linear space V is defined as the space of linear maps from V to C. Given a basis {eÎ¼}âV, the corresponding dual basis {eÎ¼}âVâ is defined by the orthonormality condition eÎ¼(eÎ½)âÎ´Î½Î¼. Every finite-dimensional linear space is isomorphic to its dual, because the two spaces necessarily have the same dimension. However, the identification of V and Vâ is not canonical, and one has considerable freedom in pairing vectors with dual vectors using some form of bilinear mapping. In Minkowski spacetime E1,3 for example, the map used is a symmetric bilinear inner-product g:E1,3ÃE1,3âR, which with respect to some basis {eÎ¼} can be written g=gÎ¼Î½eÎ¼âeÎ½. For a given vector v=vÎ¼eÎ¼âE1,3 one defines the corresponding dual vector vââvÎ¼eÎ¼âE1,3â such that vÎ¼âgÎ¼Î½vÎ½. This pairing means that the contraction of a vector v with its dual vâ gives the g-norm of v, i.e.,Â vâ(v)â¡g(v,v). In the two-spinor calculus formalism the analogous vector-dual vector pairing is defined with respect to the symplectic structures on S and SÌ. The dual of an element ÏâS is an element Ïâ:SâC belonging to Sâ such that (A.3)Ïâ(Ï)=Ï(Ï,Ï). Obviously the same relation holds between elements of SÌ and SÌâ. The symplectic maps Ïâ:VâÃVââC and ÏÌâ:VÌâÃVÌââC associated with the dual spaces are non-degenerate bivectors. To build spinors one uses distinguished canonical (a.k.a. Darboux, a.k.a. spin) bases {fa},Â {faÌ},Â {fa} and {faÌ}, which belong in V,VÌ,Vâ and VÌâ respectively, and which satisfy the relations fa(fb)=fb(fa)=Î´ba and faÌ(fbÌ)=fbÌ(faÌ)=Î´bÌaÌ. In the canonical bases the symplectic maps Ï,ÏÌ,Ïâ and ÏÌâ can be written Ï=Ïabfaâ§fb,ÏÌ=ÏaÌbÌfaÌâ§fbÌ,(A.4)Ïâ=Ïâabfaâ§fb,ÏÌâ=ÏâaÌbÌfaÌâ§fbÌ where â§ denotes the exterior product. The sets of components Ïab,ÏaÌbÌ,Ïâab and ÏÌâaÌbÌ each support the matrix representation (A.5)Ïab,ÏaÌbÌ,Ïâab,ÏâaÌbÌâ(01â10). As we remarked above Sp(2,V) is the symmetry group associated with Ï, that is, given any TâSp(2,V) we have that Ï(TÏ,TÏ)=Ï(Ï,Ï) for all Ï,ÏâV. In components this condition along with the analogous conditions pertaining to ÏÌ,Ïâ and ÏÌâ, can be written TabÏbcTdc=Ïad,TaÌbÌÏbÌcÌTdÌcÌ=ÏaÌdÌ,(A.6)TÌabÏbcTÌdc=Ïad,TÌaÌbÌÏbÌcÌTÌdÌcÌ=ÏaÌdÌ where a tilde has been used to denote the matrix contragradient TÌâ(TT)â1.

ce:section.ce:label: A.2
ce:section.ce:section-title: Lorentz transformations and spinor index gymnastics
ce:section.ce:para: We have now all of the ingredients necessary in order to define arbitrary higher order spinors (spin-tensors) and to be able to perform spinor index gymnastics. Denoting the r-times Cartesian product of a set S with itself by Sr, we define a spin-tensor of type-pqrs as a multilinear map Ï:SâpÃSÌâqÃSrÃSÌsâC, which in the canonical bases can be written (A.7)Ï=Ïa1â¦apb1â¦braÌ1â¦aÌqbÌ1â¦bÌsfa1ââ¯âfapâfb1ââ¯âfbrâfaÌ1ââ¯âfaÌqâfbÌ1ââ¯âfbÌs. When viewed as a spin-tensor field over Minkowski spacetime, the components of Ï are to be viewed as functions of xâE1,3.

A Lorentz transformation ÎâL+â has two elementary two-dimensional nonequivalent complex representations, one on S, which is denoted T(Î), and the complex-conjugate representation on SÌ, which is denoted TÌ(Î). These representations correspond to right-helicity and left-helicity two-spinors respectively. The representation TÌ(Î) on Sâ is equivalent to T(Î) on S, while the representation TÌÌ(Î) on SÌâ is equivalent to TÌ(Î) on SÌ. The carrier space of the (i,j)th irreducible representation of Sp(2,C) can be taken as the collection of spin-tensors with components Ï(a1â¦ai)(aÌ1â¦aÌj), where the notation Ï(a1â¦an) means that Ï is totally-symmetric in the indices a1,â¦,an. In this case the carrier space of the (i,j)th representation has clearly been built out of the spaces S and SÌ. Alternatively we could, in the obvious way, take any one of the three elementary combinations Sâ and SÌâ, or S and SÌâ, or SÌ and Sâ, as the building blocks for the carrier spaces of the various (i,j) representations. In this paper we choose the pair (S,SÌâ), which means that right-helicity spinors are labelled by unbarred upper indices while left-helicity spinors are labelled by barred lower indices.

Under a Lorentz transformation ÎâL+â each unbarred upper index of the components of a spin-tensor Ïaâ¦â¦â¦â¦ transforms through multiplication by a matrix Tba(Î). An unbarred lower index Ïâ¦aâ¦â¦â¦ transforms through multiplication by TÌab(Î). Obviously the barred indices transform in the same way through matrices TbÌaÌ(Î) and TÌaÌbÌ(Î). In the case of a spin-tensor field the argument xâE1,3 transforms to Îâ1x. More generally under a PoincarÃ© transformation (Î,a) with (Î,a)x=Îx+a, the argument x transforms as (Î,a)â1x=Îâ1xâÎâ1a.

To carry out spinor index gymnastics the symplectic maps are used, because these are the maps we have used to define the dual spaces. We use Ï to denote the components of these maps in keeping with the common convention in symplectic geometry. The symbol Ïµ is more commonly found in the two-spinor calculus literature. Because the components of the symplectic maps are anti-symmetric one must be careful in raising and lowering indices, for example ÏabÏa=âÏbâ Ïb. We adopt the convention that Ïab can only be used to lower an index when the repeated index is in the first slot. Similarly Ïab only raises the index when the repeated index is in the second slot. The same rules apply for barred indices, so altogether (A.8)ÏabÏa=Ïb,ÏabÏb=Ïa,ÏaÌbÌÏaÌ=ÏbÌ,ÏaÌbÌÏbÌ=ÏaÌ. In what follows we will specify how spinor index gymnastics relates to the usual spacetime index gymnastics.

ce:section.ce:label: A.3
ce:section.ce:para: Minkowski spacetime E1,3 will be viewed as a pair (R,g) where R is a real four-dimensional vector space and g:RÃRâR is a symmetric indefinite inner-product. In an orthonormal basis {eÎ¼} of R with dual basis {eÎ¼}âRâ (s.t eÎ¼(eÎ½)=Î´Î½Î¼) the inner-product g can be written g=gÎ¼Î½eÎ¼eÎ½, where the juxtaposition eÎ¼eÎ½ denotes the symmetric tensor product of eÎ¼ and eÎ½. Similarly one defines the inner-product gâ=gÎ¼Î½eÎ¼eÎ½ on Râ. The components gÎ¼Î½ and gÎ¼Î½ have the matrix representation diag(1,â1,â1,â1) and can be used to raise and lower spacetime indices in the usual way; gÎ¼Î½vÎ½=vÎ¼ etc.

To relate spinor and spacetime indices we use a representation []:E1,3(E1,3â)âH(2,C) of vectors (dual-vectors) vâE1,3(vââE1,3â) as two-dimensional Hermitian matrices [v]([vâ])âH(2,C). The representation [â ] is defined by (A.9)[v]âÏÌÎ¼vÎ¼=ÏÌÎ¼vÎ¼,[vâ]âÏÎ¼vÎ¼=ÏÎ¼vÎ¼ where ÏÎ¼ and ÏÌÎ¼ denote the following normalised Pauli spin-matrices Ï0=ÏÌ0=12(1001),Ï1=âÏÌ1=12(0110),(A.10)Ï2=âÏÌ2=12(0âii0),Ï3=âÏÌ3=12(100â1). The components of the Minkowski inner-product have numerous representations in terms of the normalised Pauli spin-matrices; (A.11)tr(ÏÎ¼ÏÌÎ½)=tr(ÏÌÎ¼ÏÎ½)=gÎ¼Î½,tr(ÏÎ¼ÏÌÎ½)=tr(ÏÌÎ¼ÏÎ½)=gÎ¼Î½, which enable one to define the Minkowski inner-product on H(2,C) as (A.12)g(v,w)=gÎ¼Î½vÎ¼wÎ½=tr(ÏÎ¼ÏÌÎ½)vÎ¼wÎ½=tr([vâ][w])â[v]â [w]. With the elements of the matrices [v] and [vâ] we can associate components of spin-tensors via vaÌa=ÏÎ¼aÌavÎ¼=ÏÎ¼aÌavÎ¼,vaaÌ=ÏÌÎ¼aaÌvÎ¼=ÏÌÎ¼aaÌvÎ¼(A.13)vÎ¼=ÏÎ¼aÌavaaÌ=ÏÌÎ¼aaÌvaÌa,vÎ¼=ÏÎ¼aÌavaaÌ=ÏÌÎ¼aaÌvaÌa. The Minkowski inner-product can be written in terms of spin-tensor components in numerous ways, for example g(v,w)=vaaÌwaÌa. The hybrid so-called van der Waerden symbols are defined as gÎ¼aaÌâÏÎ¼aaÌ,gÎ¼aaÌâÏÎ¼aaÌ,(A.14)gÎ¼aÌaâ(ÏÌÎ¼)aÌaT,gÎ¼aÌaâ(ÏÌÎ¼)aÌaT. These symbols can be consistently manipulated according to the rules of both spinor and spacetime index gymnastics. In order to obtain the numerical values of the van der Waerden symbols, and when translating expressions into expressions involving matrix operations the identifications in Eq. (A.14) must be used. Given this recipe for converting spinor indices to spacetime indices and vice versa, we obtain the following useful relations gÎ¼Î½=gÎ¼aaÌgÎ½bbÌÏabÏaÌbÌ=gÎ¼aaÌgÎ½aaÌ,gÎ¼Î½=gÎ¼aÌagÎ½bÌbÏabÏaÌbÌ=gÎ¼aÌagÎ½aÌa,gaÌabÌbâgÎ¼aÌagÎ¼bÌb=ÏabÏaÌbÌ,(A.15)gaaÌbbÌâgÎ¼aaÌgÎ¼bbÌ=ÏabÏaÌbÌ where the above expressions involving the symbols gaÌabÌb and gaaÌbbÌ can be viewed as definitions.

In general a spacetime index Î¼ will correspond to a composite spinor pair of indices aaÌ or aÌa. It should therefore be evident how spacetime tensors can be constructed from spin-tensors. Regarding the representation theory of the Lorentz group L+â, the carrier space of the (i,i)th representation of Sp(2,C) can be viewed as the space of totally symmetric tensors over spacetime with components h(Î¼1â¦Î¼2i) or h(Î¼1â¦Î¼2i). Given the above translation scheme it is clear that this is consistent with the specification given previously for the general (i,j) representations of Sp(2,C) in terms of spin-tensors.
